Posts.Content: On Jul 20, 2015 7:28 PM LFHagens wrote: On Aug 17, 2011 8:12 AM aiosub wrote: I also stopped this "poison" drug after 2 years and a half. We want quality of life, not to be like vegetables. Gppd Luck~ I noticed you posted in 2011, and it is now 2015.  What is your present health? Yes, it is 2015 & I'm alive & well.  Just today, I had an appt w/my oncologist.  So far, the breast cancer has not returned, but still I'm plagued, on a daily basis, with the Arimidex side effects.  Initially, my GP told me this would last 6 months..., but here we are.  As I am a very active nearly 65 yr old (09/07/50),  I have not allowed the lingering effects to lay claim to the qulaity of my life.  We have a gym here in the house & I workout at least 3 eves/wk....1 1/2 hrs each...hand wts, bench press, elliptical, Bowflex and treadmill.  Most days, I'm OK until between 11a-1p, when I take my pain med, Nucynta.  It's a wonderful, non-constipating opioid. Then, I take the second one about about 5 or 6p.  However, there are other days when I awaken with this burning/throbbing/tingling annoyance, about a 3 or 4, on a pain scale with 10 being the worst. Those mornings, I take Nucynta when my feet hit the floor, about 7:20 & it's out the door to walk the dog.  The second pill is about noon & a third about 6p.  This really sounds nuts, but the heating pad on my bottom is helpful getting me thru the nites, when the days start like that.  A few times, I have awakened in the night with discomfort.  It is focused on the soles of my feet, in my hands & at my butt. Never had anything like this before Arimidex. Am resigned to the fact, I'll have this forever & the only way to keep disabilities from becoming a way of life is to exercise. As long as I'm moving, I feel good, but when I stop, I feel it.  Even the EverReady Bunny has to rest sometime!  I also do 4 hrs of yard work every Saturday & volunteer 4 hrs weekly in an ER.  To stop/decrease activity allows for stiffening to set in, which then begins to limit range of motion & the less active I am the more pain I have. So, that's me in 2015. So, how are you doing?
Posts.Title: Side Effects of Arimidex After Almost 2 Years

Posts.Content: Good Morning All.  Regarding the half life of Arimidex.  I took it for 87 days & quit due to bone pain and limitations to range of motion to some joints, esp my right hip.  So, here I am, 5 yrs later & still have daily burning sensation at both butt cheeks, worse when I sit.  Sporadically, I get pain in the fingers, my feet will feel like they've been runover and my tailbone will feel like someone is driving a spike up thru it.  Altho the intensity has decreased over the yrs, it is still there everyday, for which I take pain medication.  After having stopped Arimidex 12/23/11, I saw a Rheumatologist, in Feb 2012, who said it was not arthritis, but Arimidex.  I now have cancer in the other breast.  Not metastasis or recurrence, they tell me.  I'm taking Aromasin this time & no new bone pain at day #14.  Wish me luck & I wish you luck.  If your side effects don't stop, I'm living proof it can happen.  My Dr kept telling me it would go away......haha. My step-daughter's breast cancer was diagnosed 1 month before my first one, in 2011.  She had raidation, IV chemo, Herceptin & tamoxiphen for 5 yrs.  We're awaiting her biopsy results.  I am fearful it's likely cancer of the uterus- - -another fine side effect of these lovely drugs they give us.

Posts.Content: On Sep 14, 2015 7:39 PM Cydsong wrote: On Sep 14, 2015 6:32 PM dixieEQ wrote: Not sure if I'm replying in the right place but I, too, have been taking arimidex for 2 1/2 years.  I had lumpectomy for stage I breast cancer, 12 weeks of chemo, and 35 radiation treatments prior to starting arimidex.  Have had joint pain and stiffness from the get go.  I did find some improvement with a gluten free diet. Now I am battling serious fatigue and depression and deciding the arimidex may be the culprit.  I took it upon myself to stop the medication for a trial period to see if things improve.  Today is just day 2 of not taking this medication so I've not seen any improvements yet.  But it is encouraging to know that I'm not imagining my symptoms.  I am a very active 57 year old and this fatigue is so out of charactor for me.  I can barely function at this point but have to muscle through.Please hang in there! Two days is not enough time to undue the side effects; give yourself at least 6 MONTHS!! If you aren't improving, go to an alternative health practitioner to help with the pain & fatigue. (Acupuncturist, Chinese medicine, etc.). I have had fibromyalgia for years (unrelated to my breast cancer), so I know how debilitating chronic pain can be! Western medicine has very little to offer for chronic pain but more of these damn drugs! Our doctors have, sadly, become "pushers" for the pharmaceutical companies. Yes, there has been some "success" with these drugs, but we have to have quality of life, not be fighting the side effects all the time! Some side effects of some drugs outweigh the benefits, IMO. I had double-breast cancer (right breast Stage 1; Left Stage 2; Grade 2). I had a double mastectomy, chemo, & didn't have to have radiation. The radiologist I saw (loved her!) said it's all pretty much a crap shoot anyway; she has patients who do the absolute least that recommended...i.e., lumpectomy only, no treatment(s), and their cancer never returns. Others do exactly everything to a "T" and die anyway. We're all going to die someday from something, so quality of life is imperative! I tried all 3 Aromatase Inhibitors and, lastly, Tamoxifen, all with side effects I couldn't manage, and all exacerbating, one way or another, my fibromyalgia symptoms and/or giving me new unpleasant symptoms. I'd say that, on and off, I was probably on one or the other of these drugs a total of under 2 years. I'd go off, wait a while, feel better, go on another one, etc., etc. finally I got a new, young, female doctor who basically said nothing was going to change so for me to just consider that portion of my treatment finished. I was very happy! My hubby & I said from the outset that we would make our decision(s) as the need arose based on what we knew at that time, move forward, and never look back in regret. If cancer comes back, that's what I'll do at that time. Though my health is far from perfect because of the fibromyalgia, I definitely felt better being off those other oral cancer meds. You are not alone! Give yourself some time to heal! Best of luck to you! Hi DixieEQ & Cydsong, DixieEQ I just sent you a private reply, but I now I see Cydsong's post too.  I believe, as she does, you make decisions with the info you have at hand at the time.  When the info is updated, if it has changed, then you have to re-evaluate, at that point.  Quality of life is most important to me & along with the info about my risk of recurrence & that I was a stage I, is what I based my decision on.  My family doctor had also said it would take about 6 months for the side effects to wear off.  In that area, I was not so lucky.  I deal with the bone pain everyday, confined to my butt, hands & feet---since Dec 2011.  I take an opioid twice a day & between that & my exercise, life is good. Some days are better than others.  Today is a really good one! As all the oral chemo for breast cancer are in the same family of drugs (similar chemical structure) , they all tend to have the same side effects, some, however, worse than others.  Tamoxifen is known to cause uterine cancer in some individuals.  Just what we need!! In general, this family of drugs causes bone pain & osteoporosis, which makes us more likely to fracture.   We're here for you!

Posts.Content: It is good that you continue to exercise.  I am also an avid exerciser.  Before quitting Arimidex, not only did I have the bone pain, but also significant loss of range of motion of many of my joints.  Thru stopping the poison (Arimidex) & continuing to exercise, my rangeof motion has returned.  Ladies, exercise is one of the best things you can do for yourselves to not end up crippled or in a wheelchair.  It takes your mind off your matter, causes you to breathe more deeply thus increasing blood flow & oxygen to the tissues & will help to maintain muscle strength & joint range of motion.

Posts.Content: Yes, it is a very difficult decision to make.  It comes down to quantity versus quality of life.  I had lumpectomy, 6wks of radiation & 87 days of Arimidex in 2011.  My odds of recurrence are about 11%.  My choice was quality over quantity.   I am 65. I have daily pain in my feet, hands & tailbone; not arthritis the Rheumatologist said----Arimidex.  I take an opioid twice a day.  I exercise in the gym in my home 2-3 times a week (wts, treadmill & ellipitical trainer), do 4 hrs of yardwork every Sat, volunteer 4 hrs weekly inside the ER of a local hospital & sing in a choir.  Everyone's story is different, but this is mine. I'm happy & I feel healthy.  This is just what happens to work for me.

Posts.Content: On Aug 29, 2015 1:03 AM dd6goldy wrote: I have been off of Arimidex for some time now and was placed on Letrozole generic for Femara.  I have had sever pain in my upper abdomen when ever I lay down or sit for any length of time.  Doctors can't find out what is wrong, in the mean time I am exausted because I sleep very little.  I never had this trouble before.  After I went through all the cancer treatment for breast cancer just one day I started with this pain.  Has anyone else experanced anything like this?   Does anyone know if it could be from the Letrozole.  Any ideas would be most appreacted. Joint and muscle pain are common side effects of aromatase inhibitors (AI), occurring in the hands and wrists, feet and ankles, knees, back or other parts of the body.  Altho this pain isn't supposed to be permanent, my bone pain is ongoing for 4 yrs now.  In rare cases, AIs can cause carpal tunnel syndrome.  Anti-inflammatories, special exercises or acupuncture may ease the pain. The family of AI includes Arimidex (anastrozole), Aromasin (exemestane) & Femara (letrozole), which are newer drugs than the old standby, Tamoxifen, which has a different chemical structure than AIs.  It is important, when researching, to look for the adverse effects, not just side effects.  You'll then find that unlike Tamoxifen, AIs do not increase the risk of uterine cancer, blood clots, or stroke, but they can promote bone loss (osteoporosis) and are associated with an increased risk of bone fractures and cardiovascular events.  In rare cases, a serious jawbone disorder called osteonecrosis may occur. Nothing I've found relates to your upper abdominal pain. Have you had a PET scan?

Posts.Content: I am also new to this site....looking for an answer:  how long do the Arimidex side effects last after stopping the drug?  Unlike your accts of experience with Arimidex, I've only been on it since 10/1/11, not quite 3 months & have given up (12/27/11).  Quality of life is far more important to me than quantity, after what I have been experiencing.  The hot flashes from Hell, sometimes occur nearly hourly during the afternoon & wake me at nite, despite loads of sleep meds.  I have Raynaud's & am used to being cold.  Sometimes, despite my FL location my digits will get numb from being cold. Meanwhile, sweat pours down my face & drips off my hair from the lovely heat flashes! I feel like a Sweat Hog & am embarrassed to go out in public.  Every move I make hurts.  I feel very stiff.  Even my butt hurts & then, there's also the migratory joint aches.  The Rheumatolgist said there was nothing he could do.  Arthritis medications won't help bec it's not arthritis, it's Arimidex.  All he offered was a Rx for pain medication.  All that did was contribute to the constipation caused by all the Calcium to protect my bones from Arimidex.  This is just plain absurd.  I quit.  I'd rather die in peace, than live suffering in pain & constipated.

Posts.Content: Hello Marjwat1942.  Reading your post sounds like you wrote about me. I have prior posts about my nearly 3 month long Arimidex experience & its after math & now, my second breast cancer.  See Page 5, 12/28/11, pg 24, 11/19/15 & pg 26, 9/8/16.  I seem to be getting along better with Aromasin now, than I did with Arimidex back in 2011.  Regarding bone loss, that is nothing new.  Read back to some of the pages, early on, on this site.  In 2011, I read how some women lost their teeth due to the bone loss in their jaws.  I was horrified.  Guess what? I discovered I have 4 loose front teeth about 6 months ago.  I still have daily pain...in my feet, hands & butt.  Bec of the Opioid epidemic in this country, the pendulum is now swinging far back in the opposite direction.  Physicians are very afraid & hesitant to prescribe pain meds.  I have been on an opioid since Feb 2012.  My onc recently decided I should see a Rheumatologist, I guess bec she didn't believe I had pain that warranted an opioid.  After a slew of lab tests & xrays, all the Rheu said was "your xrays are very impressive".  He then said, if I wanted to pursue treatment I should see a hand specialist, foot specialist & ortho spine physician.  Seems to me, had this been mere arthritis, he would have said so & continued to treat me himself.  After thinking about this for 2 months, I have just recently requested my records so I can read for myself what I'm dealing with.

Posts.Content: On Jul 26, 2017 5:27 PM rgday wrote: I have been on Arimidex for 15 months.  A couple of questions for others:  1.  What about memory loss?  I find I am extremely forgetful now.  2.  As far as weight loss, does anyone have any information about the HCG diet?   Homeopathic hcg drops?  Can you take the natural homeopathic hcg drops while on Arimidex? I followed WW for 5 months and lost 5 lbs.  I try to walk and exercise to alleviate joint pain, but I know less weight will be helpful also.  Thanks for any information.  Yes, we get what is known as chemo fog.  Look it up on the internet.  Of course, memory loss is also part of the normal aging process.  So, we get a double whammy. Regarding weight:  my success is attributed to decresed carbohydrates.  Check out the Glycemic index.  Lower your intake of high glycemic foods.  Increase protein.  Above all, get your body moving.  Walking is great for its aerobic benefit for your heart & lungs.  However, building muscle mass will increase your metabolic rate,(rate at which your body burns calories) aerobics won't.  Look up some strength training exercises on the internet & get started...5 days/wk. Diet alone will not make a difference.  Don't go out & by weights.  Many exercises can be done starting off seated in a chair or start off with 1# cans of fruits or vegs in your pantry.  I'm 5'5" & weigh 125.  You can do it too, but you need to alter your diet & increase your movement.  I've also found the more I move, the less pain I have.  It takes a committment to lifestyle changes. Gimmick diets work for awhile, but when you return to your eating habits, that got you where you are, there you are again!
